content.description:
This is a rad route. Start on choss shelves and move up to a nice crimp and a long move out left to gain a great shelf up high.

I used the obvious handle-shaped tree root to top out. Cleaning for a proper rock top out would require removing about a foot of dirt. Also finishing on the tree root is pretty fun.
content.protection: A bit of a tall route with a nice pointy rock in the fall zone. Bring pads and spotters.
content.location: The highball block with the tree lying diagonally on the block. This route is on the right hand side.

content.description: Start low on a good sloper, move up through some pockets to a perfect mantle. Good practice for gym climbers who would like to learn to mantle.
content.location: Just past the second water fall, you'll see a long, short wall on your left. This problem is located at the end of the wall, just before the arete. The arete is not part of the problem, and I don't think it would help.

content.description: Start low on good pockets and move up to use crimps to top out

Amazing...once you get past the choss and decide which feet aren't going to break. The top of the route is bomber rock.

Start on a big singular pocket and make your way up through jugs until a crux at the top, on bomber underclings and a perfect crimp.

Name comes from Coldplay's 'Every teardrop is a waterfall' considering all the waterfalls in the area. Also I like the song.
content.protection: Pads and a spotter(s). A large, pointy rock lies in the fall zone. Best to have a spotter for this one.
content.location: In the highball area. To the left of the downed tree.

content.description: Start low on some big holds and move right through the suspect flake. Big move to crimp rail and topout.
content.location: There are three mantles on this block. This is the left most one.
